Another great Q&A with an Eagle involved in the Olympic Games!

Boston College Alumni
August 6 at 10:27 AM Â·

As the Olympic Games wind down::: viewers have seen the iconic Olympics logo tied to many other noteworthy brands. But who makes these connections happen? Behind the scenes at the United States Olympics & Paralympic Games Committee (USOPC)::: Boston College alum Dave Mingey â€™92::: senior vice president::: partnership management & activation::: is in charge of stewarding the partnerships between corporations and Team USA. We caught up with him to talk about his role.

Q: Were you an athlete growing up?
A: I played a lot of sports growing up but focused on rowing for nine years::: getting my start on my high school rowing team where we won two national championships. At Boston College::: I was co-captain of the menâ€™s rowing team::: and then I rowed competitively for one year after graduation. My wife::: Darby â€™98::: was on the track team at BC and was a talented runner.

Q: Summer or Winter Games?
A: Summer. With more than 200 nations and territories in attendance there is a more global feel with the Summer Games. Winter Games are about one-third the total scale of the Summer Games.

Q: Favorite Boston College Athletics tradition or memory?
A: Definitely Marathon Monday. I mean::: how many campuses have one of the worldâ€™s biggest sporting events running through it? But in terms of a specific memory::: I will never forget storming the field after David Gordonâ€™s kick in 1993 that gave the Eagles a 41-39 win over Notre Dame in South Bend.

Q: How would you explain what you do with USOPC to elementary school students on Career Day?
A: Unlike almost all other National Olympic Committees::: Team USA doesnâ€™t receive any federal funding. Our athletes greatly depend on our two biggest sources of revenue: donations and corporate support. I oversee the team responsible for our key sponsorships and the marketing campaigns of numerous global and national brands such as Coca-Cola::: Nike::: and Airbnb.

Q: Has your job taken you to any interesting places?
A: Iâ€™ve worked on 14 Olympic Games and have attended 10. My first was Lillehammer in 1994.

Q: Fun fact about you?
A: In 2002::: I had the opportunity to run as a Torchbearer for the Salt Lake 2002 Olympic Winter Games. I ran my leg of the route in Brooklyn::: N.Y. I remember standing in my assigned spot::: waiting for the torch to arrive when an Olympic official on a motorcycle rushed over to me to yell above the noise of the helicopters overhead::: â€œRemember::: once you begin running::: you will be the only person in the world responsible for getting this thing to the Opening Ceremony.â€ It was surreal.

-\-\-\-\-\-\-\-\
Like this story? Meet other BC alumni behind the scenes at the Olympics: https://bit.ly/2VCpXMp

Dana Jozefczyk â€™06 is the associate general counsel of intellectual property for Team USA's Olympic & Paralympic Games Committee (USOPC). She handles intellectual property rights::: copyrights::: and trademarks for the worldâ€™s biggest games.

She answered a few questions about the Games::: the Heights and more â¬‡ï¸

Boston College Alumni
July 23 at 9:28 AM Â·

Who gets to wear the Olympic ringsâ€”and howâ€™d that logo get there? Youâ€™ve seen them on cups and hats and in commercials: the five colorful::: intertwined Olympic rings that serve as the iconic symbol of the worldâ€™s biggest athletic competition. We caught up with Boston College alum Dana Jozefczyk â€™06::: associate general counsel of intellectual property for the United States Olympics & Paralympic Games Committee (USOPC)::: who handles intellectual property rights::: copyrights::: and trademarks for the worldâ€™s biggest games.

Q: Can I put the Olympic rings on this post?
A: The short answer is no. The USOPC is a nonprofit and we rely on sponsors to provide resources to send Team USA to the Games. BC isnâ€™t an official sponsor or licensee::: so we ask that you not use the rings and other marks.

Q: Summer or Winter Olympics?
A: I really love them all! My senior year::: I remember sitting on the Mods couches for hours with my friends::: watching every single televised snowboarding event during the 2006 winter games in Turin::: Italy.

Q: Favorite Boston College Athletics tradition?
A: During my junior year::: 6-7 of us rented an RV and drove to a campground outside South Bend::: Ind.::: for the BC-ND game. We drove out there in one day. I remember playing a lot of cards on that little RV table.

Q: Has your job taken you to any interesting places?
A: Iâ€™ve toured the training center at Lake Placid. My dad played hockey growing up and we are all hockey fans::: so it was a big deal to see where the Miracle on Ice took place.

Q: Fun fact about you?
A: Iâ€™m famous among my friends and colleagues for mixing up idiomatic expressions. I say things like â€œhorse and pony showâ€ and â€œthe egg doesnâ€™t fall far from the tree.â€

Q: Whatâ€™s a typical day at the office?
A: With the Games coming up::: weâ€™re getting a lot of reports of people infringing intellectual property. We know how excited people are about the Olympic Games. I do a lot of education on how to switch up their designs and usage.

Q: So::: can I put the Olympic rings on this post?
A: Sorry::: the answer is still a hard (but nice) no! However::: since BC is a participant in our Olympians Made Here (OMH) campaign::: youâ€™re free to use OMH assets to cheer on all the collegiate athletes competing in Tokyo!

Unless I am proven wrong I think our exempted kids are looking at an emotionally difficult year being signaled::: segregated and deemed anti-vax or anti-science. I hope and pray BC wonâ€™t take part of segregation and cancel culture and will lead the Christian way with truth::: kindness::: compassion::: mercy::: freedom of conscience:::mora
l ethics toward those who uphold sacredness of life and the gifts from
the Holy Spirit pertaining to healing::: discernment::: wisdom & knowledge. In God is whom I trust and the power conveyed to me by the Holy Spirit to speak out and guide my children in matters of faith & medical decisions.
column4: Anyone who wants to join us in fighting BC against this mandate::: DM me
column5:
The truth is in the eye of the beholder. Many people right now are blinded by ignorance of what they donâ€™t know. You donâ€™t know what you donâ€™t know and that is not your fault as long as you are not controlled by money::: fear or politics. Itâ€™s everyone personal responsibility to be a critical thinker and seek truth and discernment from a system that has been corrupted by power::: greed lies:::bribery::: extortion::: censoring and canceling of dissenting voices from the â€œofficial narrativeâ€ of those in power including forced experimental vaccine first of itâ€™s kind in the history of vaccinations. Some of us are people of science. I personally am a well
educated pharmacist registered in multiple states not anti-vax but rather anti experimental forced gene code treatment. I personally follow the type of science that welcomes open discussion without censoring opposing or differing voices. The science that welcome more than one form of treatment and the science not controlled by money::: politics::: extortion or coercion. We have no idea about long term effects including infertility or vascular damage which we now know myocarditis is possibly one of them. This is why informed consent is critical here and students and people should have the right to opt out. Vaccines are not the only way to stop the spread and treat but the â€œofficial voice$â€ have decided we only have one choice. You submit or you will be silenced::: cancelled::: told you are a moron::: or go somewhere else. You are not wanted!

Varun Vincent - who earned his master's from Carroll School of Management at BC in 2013 - experienced firsthand the COVID-19 shortages in India::: as his father could not get oxygen or an ICU bed.

column3:
When we attend schools/
universities::: we are often taught how to lead and help build communities to make a difference even if in a small way. But seldom do we get the strong backup and support that we need to succeed. I want to express my sincere gratitude to Boston College::: its staff and all its alumni for their continued support. Going to BC was hands down the best decision I ever made! Thank you!
#WeAreBC
#BreatheForIndia

column17:
Thought I would share my most recent email to Jack Dunn and BC Leadership. To date::: I have not received a single reply to any of my communications.
The silence is deafening.

Dear Mr. Dunn:::

I was thrilled to learn::: from Jennifer Eagan::: that Boston College has submitted a plan to the City of Boston to allow for the 25% capacity in Alumni Stadium with the intent of allowing up to 2 guests per graduate. This news has been shared and is being well received.

Given the approximately 4500 attendees between undergraduate and graduate students::: it would lead me to believe that BC is considering holding two sessions thereby allowing each graduate the opportunity to have at least 2 guests in attendance.

This is the solution I and the almost 3200 hundred supporters of my petition believe is the correct outcome based on the relaxing of the capacity and the three weeks available to make the necessary changes. Allowing only one guest may seem like a compromise but in all honesty it will put additional stress on the student having to choose which parent should attend. I am sure you agree that these students have had enough stress and strain this year and we should not burden them with more.

While I recognize Northeastern University is only allowing one guest::: their graduation is this weekend and prior to the May 10th change. However::: I will mention that they are holding separate ceremonies for their graduate and undergraduate students to allow for guests.

Mr. Dunn::: I appreciate that Boston College is taking the necessary steps to do what is right for these students and parents. These past 15 months have been less than ideal for all of us and these seniors have truly missed out on so many wonderful opportunities afforded to prior BC students. To celebrate with their families is a way to bring joy back to what has been a less than joyous year.

While my emails have focused on the Alumni Stadium capacity situation::: I would be remiss if I did not mention the individual college diploma ceremonies. It is my understanding that past Commencements started in Alumni with speakers::: then the students go to their respective colleges for the formal handing out of the diplomas.

If past practice is to be followed this year then then the updated guidelines do not have a capacity restriction for events held under a tent as long as social distancing is followed and the tent is open at least 50%. This is wonderful news for parents to attend the individual diploma ceremonies and to share in the joy of seeing their child walk across the stage and be handed their hard earned Boston College diplomas.

Mr. Dunn::: I look forward to learning more about the changes being made to Commencement to allow parents and their children to celebrate together. And::: I am confident that the BC leadership team will do what is right.

Sincerely:::

Christine Swanson

column21:
No more excuses BC! Guests can be allowed.
Here is my letter to leadership that has yet to receive a reply.
Subject: Change in stadium capacity allows for in person attendance

Dear Father Leahy::: Dr. Quigley::: Commencement Committee Members and Deans:::

As you are aware::: Governor Baker and the City of Boston have relaxed their stadium capacity requirements to allow for 25% attendance effective May 10th::: 2021. With this news::: our petition has gathered in strength with almost 2600 signatures to date. This is just over a 25% increase since my first email to you on Friday. I invite you to read the comments provided by parents and students requesting a change to allow for in person attendance. http://chng.it/
8bZ99XNY

Given capacity limitation was the reason BC gave for not allowing in person attendance::: the relaxation of this restriction has been received with great enthusiasm and provides Boston College the flexibility of changing their very restrictive Commencement plans to allow for parents and guests to attend.

I recognize that some roadblocks may still exist and I would like to provide some thoughts around overcoming these roadblocks and doing what is right for the students and parents.

Time crunch-with just under a month until Commencement how can you effectively plan?
Solution: I am confident there are multiple large event coordinators in Boston that would welcome the opportunity to assist BC with this undertaking.
Parents and students recognize that time is short and we understand that the planning may not be perfect but to be allowed to share in this joyous event with our children is more important than a perfectly executed plan.

Still do not have capacity with 4500 students and honored guests scheduled:
With a stadium that seats 44:::000::: 25% capacity is 11:::000.
You can hold two sessions-Underg
rads in the morning and Graduates in the afternoon.
This will allow 2 guests per student and allow for social distancing.
It will allow time between sessions to do the necessary cleaning.
Reduce the number of honored guests and facility scheduled to attend.
Isnâ€™t it more important to have the parents and guests in attendance?
It will demonstrate BCâ€™s commitment to their students and parents!

Short time for notification to parents:
This is not an issue as most parents are planning on being on campus to move their children out on the 24th.
Remote learners still have time to make travel plans and get vaccinated::: if they have not already done so.

On behalf of the almost 2600 parents and students who have signed the petition::: I ask that Boston College do what is right for the students and parents. There are no excuses left not to.

Sincerely:::

Christine Swanson

In a letter to the BC Community::: University President William P. Leahy::: S.J.::: has announced that Commencement will take place on May 24 in Alumni Stadium.

Because of COVID-19 health and capacity regulations::: attendance::: unfortunately::: will be limited to graduates::: senior administrators::: honorary degree recipients::: and other select members of the community. All Commencement events will be livestreamed.

READ: http://on.bc.edu/BCCommencement21
column3:
All of us recognize the disappointment among parents and loved ones over not being able to attend Commencement in-person. We had held our Commencement announcement in the hope of securing a different outcome::: but with COVID-19 cases continuing to rise in Boston and across the Commonwealth of Massachusetts::: the City of Boston issued its â€œAdvisory Regarding In-Person Commencement and Graduationâ€ on April 6::: which states: â€œCommencements or graduations held outdoors in venues with a capacity of greater than 5:::000 are limited to 12% of total capacity.â€ Given our staging needs and social distancing requirements::: Boston College can accommodate less than 5:::000 individuals in Alumni Stadium::: with 4:::500 of that total reserved for students eligible to receive their degrees. That limits the remaining capacity to senior administrators:::
deans::: honorary degree recipients::: faculty marshals::: and medical and security personnel.

Locally::: Harvard University and MIT have announced that they are hosting virtual Graduation ceremonies this year. Boston University is also hosting Commencement for graduates only. Northeastern University has proposed allowing one guest per graduate::: but it has not received City approval.

We ask you for your understanding as we prepare for Commencement on May 24::: and invite families to view the livestreamed ceremonies at: http://
on.bc.edu/
Commencement2021

column67:
This is the email I sent to BC Leadership.

Dear Father Leahy::: Dr. Quigley::: Commencement Committee Members and Deans:::

As you are aware::: Governor Baker and the City of Boston have relaxed their stadium capacity requirements to allow for 25% attendance effective May 10th::: 2021. With this news::: our petition has gathered in strength with almost 2600 signatures to date. This is just over a 25% increase since my first email to you on Friday. I invite you to read the comments provided by parents and students requesting a change to allow for in person attendance. http://chng.it/
8bZ99XNY

Given capacity limitation was the reason BC gave for not allowing in person attendance::: the relaxation of this restriction has been received with great enthusiasm and provides Boston College the flexibility of changing their very restrictive Commencement plans to allow for parents and guests to attend.

I recognize that some roadblocks may still exist and I would like to provide some thoughts around overcoming these roadblocks and doing what is right for the students and parents.

Time crunch-with just under a month until Commencement how can you effectively plan?
Solution: I am confident there are multiple large event coordinators in Boston that would welcome the opportunity to assist BC with this undertaking.
Parents and students recognize that time is short and we understand that the planning may not be perfect but to be allowed to share in this joyous event with our children is more important than a perfectly executed plan.

Still do not have capacity with 4500 students and honored guests scheduled:
With a stadium that seats 44:::000::: 25% capacity is 11:::000.
You can hold two sessions-Underg
rads in the morning and Graduates in the afternoon.
This will allow 2 guests per student and allow for social distancing.
It will allow time between sessions to do the necessary cleaning.
Reduce the number of honored guests and facility scheduled to attend.
Isnâ€™t it more important to have the parents and guests in attendance?
It will demonstrate BCâ€™s commitment to their students and parents!

Short time for notification to parents:
This is not an issue as most parents are planning on being on campus to move their children out on the 24th.
Remote learners still have time to make travel plans and get vaccinated::: if they have not already done so.

On behalf of the almost 2600 parents and students who have signed the petition::: I ask that Boston College do what is right for the students and parents. There are no excuses left not to.

Sincerely:::

Christine Swanson

column71:
Thought I would share my most recent email to Jack Dunn and BC Leadership. To date::: I have not received a single reply to any of my communications.
The silence is deafening.

Dear Mr. Dunn:::

I was thrilled to learn::: from Jennifer Eagan::: that Boston College has submitted a plan to the City of Boston to allow for the 25% capacity in Alumni Stadium with the intent of allowing up to 2 guests per graduate. This news has been shared and is being well received.

Given the approximately 4500 attendees between undergraduate and graduate students::: it would lead me to believe that BC is considering holding two sessions thereby allowing each graduate the opportunity to have at least 2 guests in attendance.

This is the solution I and the almost 3200 hundred supporters of my petition believe is the correct outcome based on the relaxing of the capacity and the three weeks available to make the necessary changes. Allowing only one guest may seem like a compromise but in all honesty it will put additional stress on the student having to choose which parent should attend. I am sure you agree that these students have had enough stress and strain this year and we should not burden them with more.

While I recognize Northeastern University is only allowing one guest::: their graduation is this weekend and prior to the May 10th change. However::: I will mention that they are holding separate ceremonies for their graduate and undergraduate students to allow for guests.

Mr. Dunn::: I appreciate that Boston College is taking the necessary steps to do what is right for these students and parents. These past 15 months have been less than ideal for all of us and these seniors have truly missed out on so many wonderful opportunities afforded to prior BC students. To celebrate with their families is a way to bring joy back to what has been a less than joyous year.

While my emails have focused on the Alumni Stadium capacity situation::: I would be remiss if I did not mention the individual college diploma ceremonies. It is my understanding that past Commencements started in Alumni with speakers::: then the students go to their respective colleges for the formal handing out of the diplomas.

If past practice is to be followed this year then then the updated guidelines do not have a capacity restriction for events held under a tent as long as social distancing is followed and the tent is open at least 50%. This is wonderful news for parents to attend the individual diploma ceremonies and to share in the joy of seeing their child walk across the stage and be handed their hard earned Boston College diplomas.

Mr. Dunn::: I look forward to learning more about the changes being made to Commencement to allow parents and their children to celebrate together. And::: I am confident that the BC leadership team will do what is right.

Sincerely:::

Christine Swanson

column73: As an alum & parent::: not only is it incredibly disappointing that I can't watch my daughter graduate in person but with the late notification of the decision::: I would have thought there would have been more conveyed about the depth of their efforts to try different configurations to make it happen and why it just couldn't. Once again::: Notre Dame beats us - they're allowing 2 guests. Yes it's Indiana::: but how about USC? They're doing multiple days. So many options & ideas just even on this post. Separate graduate school commencement from undergrad::: limit faculty to dept. heads::: do multiple days and/or multiple sections::: etc. I'm grateful there IS a graduation - my heart broke for the class of 2020. I remember my BC graduation like it was yesterday. I certainly hope cost was not a factor at all since no doubt this will have a long term fundraising impact...I join with so many on this post with my immense disappointment and sadness in how BC has handled this::: especially when I've been impressed with most of their efforts this past crazy year.

column80:
Here is the email I sent to the BC leadership team.

Thank you in advance for taking the time to read and consider my email below.

My name is Christine Swanson and I am a mother of a 2021 graduate. I am also the person who drafted and distributed the following petition: http://chng.it/
8bZ99XNY which has received over 2100 signatures from parents and students requesting a change to the current plans for Commencement. Please take a few moments to read all the wonderful comments and requests for change.

As of the writing of this email::: the BC Covid positivity rate .2%. To add::: many parents have been vaccinated in preparation for attending the graduation.

Since the notice about Commencement was sent to parents on April 13th::: I have done quite a bit of research on the guidelines set by the state on March 22::: 2021 and the City of Bostonâ€™s addendum on April 6th. Those guidelines are as follows:

https://
www.mass.gov/
doc/
commencement-gui
dance/download

https://
docs.google.com/
document/d/
18IITuP2QRCIWQbr
i_z_EIggM810QGY
6V1chB8AfNCKk/
mobilebasic

Alumni Stadium does fall within the Boston city limits but a large portion of the campus does not. I have communicated with Mayor Fuller of Newton who indicated that these decisions were BCâ€™s not the City of Newton. Based on my research::: I would like to propose some options:

The current Commencement population is 4500::: this includes approximately 2400 undergrad and 2000 grad students and honored attendees. I appreciate the desire to have all 4500 in attendance but the reality is that the grad students have been able to attend their undergrad ceremony with their guests and family in the past. The current undergrads have not.
Proposed very viable options:
i. Split the grad and undergrad ceremonies into two separate celebrations. One in the morning and one in the afternoon or across 2 days.

ii. OR-require students to register their guests and provide confirmation of a negative PCR or vaccination.

iii. OR-hold two events across 2 days

iv. OR-hold the ceremony just for the undergrads

v. OR-hold simultaneous ceremonies across campus for each of the colleges-Nursin
g::: Arts and Sciences::: Management::: etc. The speakers could be streamed to each of the locations from Alumni

Again::: not all of BC is within city limit so this can done.

We are raising the next generation who will shape the world. These individuals need to be problems solvers and solutions based thinkers. Wouldnâ€™t it set a great example::: to these students::: for BC to do the same and create a solution to the issue surrounding guests not attending graduation. In other words::: doesnâ€™t BC promote themselves as problem solvers? The hypocrisy is clear as day.

If Georgetown and Stanford can have a last minute change in plans and allow for guests::: why canâ€™t BC? If Notre Dame::: UConn::: Northeastern::: UNH::: Emerson and others have figured out a way to allow guests to attend while maintaining COVID requirements::: why canâ€™t BC?

These students have lost so much over the past year and half and to take away the celebratory time with their family is just wrong::: heartless::: cruel and will have long term ramifications not only to the students but to BCâ€™s reputation and future financial endowments.

I also would like to share::: that there is a ground swell of legacy alums who have actively begun a movement to cease any and all contributions to Boston College due to their lack of thought and consideration to the class of 2021. These folks are also seeking to contact large private and commercial donors to do the same. This would be most unfortunate but as I say to my children â€œActions have Consequencesâ€.

On behalf of over 2100 individuals who have signed the petition requesting a change::: I ask that Boston College do the right thing for the students and parents and make this happen.

column1: Early results of a timely pandemic study by Boston College psychologist Joshua Hartshorne show that increased screen time by children is likely an indicator of family distress.  BC.EDU 'The babysitter of last resort'
column3: The researcher states::: â€œI was surprised how closely the increased screen time results tracked school and daycare closures.â€ Really? Then heâ€™s the only one. Every family I know is in distress::: and has been for almost a year now. Yes::: all our kids are on screens a lot. This does not seem like news.
column4: I could not disagree more with this assessment. Increased screen time was forced upon our children as a result of the lack of in-person learning::: and as the primary means of communicating with friends whom they were forbidden to see in person.  This article is nothing more than an attempt to shame working parents who are not only focusing on working remotely while at the same time overseeing their childrenâ€™s online learning. A child sitting in front of a computer for online learning for 6+ hours is not a direct result of the sudden decrease in adult â€œcaretaker availabilityâ€. Rather it is a direct result of decisions made by our educators and policymakers to keep our children out of school and rely on online instruction.

Boston College President William P. Leahy::: S.J.::: has issued a statement::: and co-signed a statement by Jesuit college and university presidents::: condemning the events in Washington::: D.C.::: and calling for adherence to the nation's democratic principles.  BC.EDU Statement on events of January 6
column3: Fully agree with BC.
column4: For starters: I will praise or tolerate any form of peaceful protest::: right or wrong. I will reject any form of non-defensive (using the clear and present danger standard) violence or mayhem. Can we all come together on this basic declaration? Can we hear each other? We are talking past each other. It is not enough for us to oppose anotherâ€™s assertion. We must assess their needs in a spirit of brotherhood and sisterhood. We must see past the issue at hand::: and try to heal the sources of pain that we see. Let us bring our issues to the table and discuss our needs and concerns like adults. Let us look at the painful legacy of racism::: opiates::: crack::: industrial collapse::: depression::: housing and health care shortages. Let us face these things without being defensive and territorial. I donâ€™t care if another does wrong - that compels me to behave correctly with compassion and care for their whole person. Iâ€™ve made mistakes in my life. I have said unkind things. I will fail again. I need to serve more. All of us::: as graduates of Boston College::: have an educational advantage not granted to all of our brothers and sisters. We also have an obligation to serve first::: as we have been granted so much. Letâ€™s have the conversations we need to have::: and build the world with hearts afire.

column9: Hey BC::: I'm pretty disappointed in your use of this photo. This event was planned separately from BC and on the parish grounds::: not university property. BC has a history of ignoring racism on campus. It's good that you're making initial steps toward rectifying those wrongs. But the use of this photo makes it look like this event was planned and backed by the university. That is simply untrue. This was an effort planned by the Jesuits in formation who simply attend BC. Some of those who planned this even wanted to make sure that credit was not taken by the university. This is a disingenuous gesture. I look forward to BC committing itself more fully to racial justice::: a process that is long overdue. But please reconsider the message you are sending::: when part of your message needs to be one of repentance::: reconciliation::: and reparation. -Class of 2020

column1: Rest In Peace Officer Marano. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family.  Boston College Police Department October 3::: 2020 at 1:39 PM Â·  It is with profound sadness that we announce the passing of former BC Police Officer Joey Marano. Officer Marano::: who had been battling cancer::: served the Boston College community for more than 22 years. Officer Marano was a well known and beloved member of this community and our department. He was known to always put people and the community he served first.  During his time as a full-time police officer with Boston College::: Joey worked simultaneously as a full time Firefighter/Paramedic with Somerville Fire Department and later became a Reserve Officer with the Town of Foxboro Police Dept.  Please join us as we send our prayers and positive thoughts to Joey and his family during this most difficult time.  Funeral services have not been announced as of yet. #gonebutnevereverforgotten

column3: As an alumnae and Boston resident::: I am disappointed in the inadequate testing plan of BC. I can only imagine positive numbers would have been much lower had you done what other Boston higher ed institutions of your caliber and size are doing- testing of all on campus students every 3-4 days. Instead BC only did initial testing and then tested symptomatic students or those in contact with a positive case. Meanwhile::: down the road::: BU which has a smaller endowment and a student population more than twice the size of BC::: tests every 3-4 days and has fewer cases than BC. Now the governor has had to step in to assist with contact tracing at the expense of MA residents. BC dropped the ball on this::: and the communities of Newton::: Brookline and Boston are also being affected.

column13: Itâ€™s devastating how many people have died this year from or with Covid::: but we are overlooking another group of casualties that could far exceed that number - our youth. In our effort to keep a viral illness from going viral::: we are playing Russian roulette with the mental health of a generation.  We need to protect those at-risk but we can't do so by hijacking the well-being of our kids without paying a far higher price.  We are counting test results to diagnose the health of BC students::: it's surrounding neighbors::: and that of our nation::: while failing to recognize or assess any other health issue - including ones they are far more likely to be impacted by.  Suicide is the second leading cause of death for kids ages 12-25::: yet there has been zero concern posted on this chain or from the school over what the ramifications are of keeping kids isolated::: in fear of having too much human contact - and disciplined if they do.  Suicide is expected to double this year. In my hometown weâ€™ve had more kids kill themselves since May than weâ€™ve lost state-wide to covid (for teens/kids).  Any parent of a child in college::: especially freshmen who donâ€™t know people yet::: hears the distress in our kidsâ€™ voices. Countless friends have said the same thing about their own kids at schools across the country.  My daughter has been screened 4 times for Covid (no symptoms) since she arrived at BC. Where is the screening for mental health?  The rise in positive tests only underscore how high the survival rate is for Covid. As of this week::: according to the CDC::: the survival rates are 99.5% or higher for ages up 0 to 69. For ages 70 and up::: the survival rate is 94.6%. With this data::: we know who we need to protect::: and we donâ€™t do so by putting our kids in danger of other health issues.  We keep asking our college kids and our youth to â€œdo their partâ€ but what are the at-risk groups (and the rest of us) doing to protect the them from depression::: anxiety::: suicide::: etc...?  I know my 80 year old parents donâ€™t want their grandkids held hostage to assuage the fears of others.

There is your answerâ€”and I didnâ€™t even need 1.4 million dollars to figure that out!
column4: I am very happy to see BC Lynch School getting this money. Forgive me but as an old math teacher in her 70â€™s::: I am a still a little apprehensive. Since Iâ€™ve been around weâ€™ve had: arithmetic::: modern math::: new math::: back to basic::: the Standards::: common core::: etc. It seems every 15 to 20 years some young PhDâ€™s and curriculum directors need to make names for themselves and come up with a â€œ betterâ€ way to teach math. My experience is that most methods work if you have well trained ( solid in math and pedagogy)::: loving teachers who are fun to be with and tailor their instruction to the individual student. I realize this is just anecdotal evidence::: so we need the $1.4 million. The love and caring; the make it fun and real; the dedication and hard work of teachers::: parents and students... column15: As a current student at Boston College::: I am embarrassed to be a part of the Boston College Community. How can we::: as a University::: claim to be men and women of others if we refuse to genuinely be allies and advocate for the Black community? In Father Leahy's statement::: he asked "how we at Boston College::: members of an academic and faith community::: can and should respond to the humane::: racist behavior so evident last week in Minneapolis." Father Leahy's suggested responses were prayer::: the condemnation of the racial prejudice and profound injustice leading to the death of George Floyd::: and remaining people animated by faith::: hope::: and love. My interpretation of these responses did not include sending Boston College Police Officers to police the communities fighting for justice against brutality.  Time and time again::: the Boston College community has experienced racially-motiva ted hate crimes and systemic racism present within the Boston College higher administration. Time and time again::: the Boston College administrative response has failed to unite the Boston College community against racially-motiva ted hate crimes::: racism::: or discrimination. This SILENCE is compliance. This SILENCE further oppresses the Black Community at Boston College. This SILENCE is a part of the deeply ingrained::: systemic problem that further allows for racialist sentiment and oppression to continue on our campus. This SILENCE is not what "men and women for others" would do in the face of 400+ year of oppression and discrimination against Black Americans.
column16: Died while in custody is very passive language. It was determined to be a homicide::: he was murdered::: likely intentionally.
column17: "How we at Boston College can and should respond?" Action. Admission of the struggle at BC::: for many decades::: to respond adequately to racial tensions. Admission of not knowing just how bad it has been::: because you have not listened::: have chosen to not see. Admission of the reality of white privilege in America and in the beloved "Jesuit tradition:::" which grew side by side with colonialism. Take action. Words are not enough. As St James said::: "as the body without spirit is dead::: so faith without deeds is dead."
column18: Iâ€™m an Alum & this was poorly thought out and worded. George Floyd was murdered* he didnâ€™t just magically die in police custody- he had a knee strategically placed on his neck and 2 others on his back. While it is unfair and unjust it is not uncommon and Black people in America die under these circumstances very frequently. Familiarize yourself with the most recent police murders of innocent black men and women- Breonna Taylor::: Amoud Aubrey::: David McAtee& Sean Reed. Lastly::: I hope that there is a plan of action in addition to asking for feedback.
column19: The word is "murder"::: Fr. Leahy.

column21: Who authorized the dispatch of BCPD to the protest in Dorchester today?
column22: A statement isnâ€™t far-reaching enough and isnâ€™t reflective of the Jesuit call to action. As a start::: hereâ€™s a petition we::: as BC alumni::: can endorse and sign: https:// forms.gle/ eyFUcBoL3NSnBg5L 9  â€œAs an institution with over 3.4 billion dollars in net assets::: it is not only our responsibility to support and educate our students::: but to contribute in some tangible way to the fight for justice and equality. There are many other pedagogical institutions that have made statements on the matter::: but a statement itself will not be enough. As kind of a sentiment as it is::: thoughts and prayers will not suffice. It is evident that too often most sentiments expressed towards the mourning black community end up being empty promises. We have failed our minority communities time and time again::: and it is simply unacceptable to flounder again during this historic period. We::: the students of Boston College::: are calling upon you::: our faculty and administration::: for action. We request that you donate to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. As quoted from their official website::: the NAACP was founded in 1909 with a mission to â€˜ensure the political::: educational::: social::: and economic equality of all citizens::: to achieve equality of rights and eliminate race prejudice among the citizens of the United States::: to remove all barriers of racial discrimination through democratic processes::: to seek enactment and enforcement of federal::: state::: and local laws securing civil rights:::â€™ and to educate about and combat racial discrimination. Further::: we expect the institution to explicitly express their support and solidarity for the Black Lives Matter movement.â€
